revisions.rev:
{{ infobox football tournament | name = Women's Div. I Soccer Championship | logo = | caption = | founded = 1982 | region = | number of teams = 64 | current champions = [[Stanford Cardinal|Stanford]] | most successful club = [[North Carolina Tar Heels women's soccer|North Carolina]] (20 titles) | broadcasters = | motto = | website = [http://www.ncaa.com/sports/soccer-women/d1 NCAA.com] | current = }} '''NCAA Women's Soccer Championships''' are divided into three divisions. This article lists '''[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] Women's [[college soccer|soccer]] championships'''.[http://www.ncaa.org/wps/ncaa?ContentID=35407 NCAA Women's Soccer Championships Statistics and Records], ''NCAA.org''
==Division I== The NCAA began conducting a Women's Division I Soccer Championship tournament in 1982 with a 12-team tournament. Currently, the tournament field consists of 64 teams. The semifinals and final of the tournament, held at a single site every year, are collectively known as the Women's College Cup (analogous to the College Cup in men's soccer). Historically, [[North Carolina Tar Heels women's soccer|North Carolina]] has been the dominant school in Division I women's soccer. Known widely as one of the most successful collegiate programs in any NCAA sport, the Tar Heels have won an astounding 20 national championships of the 29 NCAA tournaments contested. Also, they have reached the College Cup 25 times. Head coach [[Anson Dorrance]] is considered the greatest women's soccer coach in NCAA history, leading the Tar Heels since the inception of the program in 1979. Other successful schools include [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish|Notre Dame]] (3 titles), [[Portland Pilots|Portland]] (2 titles), and [[Santa Clara Broncos|Santa Clara]] (1 title).
===2011 Tournament=== The 2011 Championship tournament began on November 11, 2011. Semifinals will be held on Friday, December 2, with the championship game on December 4 at [[Kennesaw State University Soccer Stadium]], [[Kennesaw, Georgia]]. The games will be televised on [[ESPN2]] and [[ESPN3.com]]. '''Regional winners after one round:''' * Stanford, South Carolina, California, Boston College, Auburn, Maryland, Illinois, Oklahoma State * Virginia, Washington State, Virginia Tech, Texas A&M, Memphis, Louisville, Portland, Florida State * Wake Forest, Boston University, Marquette, Penn State, North Carolina, Baylor, Central Florida, Florida * UCLA, San Diego, Miami (Fl.), Long Beach State, Ohio State, Milwaukee, Georgia, Duke '''Second round winners:''' * Stanford, Boston College, Maryland, Oklahoma State * Virginia, Virginia Tech, Louisville, Florida State * Wake Forest, Penn State, North Carolina, Central Florida * San Diego, Long Beach State, Ohio State, Duke '''Third round results:''' *Stanford 2â0 Boston College *Oklahoma State 1â0 Maryland *Virginia 4â0 Virginia Tech *Florida State 2â0 Louisville *Wake Forest 4â2 Penn State *Central Florida 1(5)â1(4) North Carolina *Long Beach State 1â0 San Diego State *Duke 2â1 Ohio State '''Quarterfinals''' *Stanford 2â1 Oklahoma State *Florida State 3â0 Virginia *Wake Forest 3â0 Central Florida *Duke 2â0 Long Beach State '''Semifinals''' *Stanford 3â0 Florida State *Duke 4â1 Wake Forest '''National Championship''' *Stanford 1-0 Duke
